title: What is the worst album ever released by the Beatles? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have to admit I over thought this question, because immediately I thought “worst in what terms: song selection? placement of songs from start to end? initial sales?” but I calmed down after reminding myself “hey man it’s relative to one’s preference..” Like most questions of this ilk the answer lies within the individual’s taste - I’ve talked with people who saw no reason to listen to “Meet The Beatles” while others couldn’t figure out why on earth “Sgt. Pepper” is still in print. And I’ve met a couple of people who didn’t make it past “Glass Onion” because “if the rest of the album sounds like this I can’t last for two records…..” so it’s truly a matter of taste. Here’s a story related to the question. Years ago I worked in the Dallas Texas branch of Capitol Records. One of the senior guys was retiring but I had a chance to chat with him off and on. I quizzed him about Capitol in the ’60s and of course The Beatles. He said ‘the only album by them we lost money on was Yesterday and Today, because of the cover debacle. Once that cleared up it finally made a profit.’ So in the short term financial aspect you could say the Y&T album was the worst released during the Beatles’ time together. I should mention what a difference wording makes in asking a question such as this. Had it been “what is the worst Beatles album ever released?” that would have opened the field to repackages in which case my choices would be a tie between the 1982 offering “Reel Music” and 1976’s “Rock N Roll Music - examples of how to package great music badly. Both had horrendous covers: the inside jacket to “RNR Music” sporting images of a ’57 Chevy, a jukebox, Marilyn Monroe, and a glass of (I’m guessing) Coca-Cola which also serves as the label design. It looked as though it was designed for a collection of ’50s hits. “Reel Music” isn’t much better - get past the amateurish renditions of the Beatles from the various films and you come upon a “booklet” that looked like it had been put together by the romantic partner of someone in the art department instead of an actual artist. Okay rant over. I provided responses which I hope proved helpful.

There are a few candidates (comments below relate to the UK versions): With the Beatles - no singles on it, lots of covers, some good originals but few standouts. Pretty short too. Beatles For Sale - made when the Beatles were tired and jaded, has covers, some songs that don’t feel completed, few standouts. Also short. Magical Mystery Tour - not really an album, released as a double EP and then made it into an album years later by adding singles and B-sides. The double EP has 6 songs - 2 are great (I am the Walrus, Fool on the Hill), 1 decent (Magical Mystery Tour), other 3 are amongst the weakest songs they released (Flying, Blue Jay Way,Your Mother Should Know). Whole concept is a muddled and a bit silly (the cover, costumes, way it was released as not a proper album). Yellow Submarine - again, not a proper album. Released in the UK as 4 new songs and then the George Martin orchestral soundtrack (so not by the Beatles). In the US it was more of a compilation album using previously released songs. The 4 new songs (apart from the fun Hey Bulldog) were all throwaways that hadn’t been seen as fit to release on previous albums (Its All Too Much, All Together Now, Only a Northern Song). Let it Be - a muddled album that lost its original concept (playing live, no overdubs) with the exact opposite (lush Phil Spector productions with added strings and choirs). Mismatched result is rather odd, leaving it more of a what could have been - the Beatles were splitting up and had clearly lost interest in this point. Songwriting is also uneven - Maggie May, For You Blue, Dig It - all inessential filler that would be best skipped, personally not a fan of the saccharine Long & Winding Road either. But remaining songs have some standout classics (Let it Be, Get Back) and there is a great feel on the ‘live’’ tracks that remain truer to the concept, with some great playing recorded on the roof. So a good but not great album. Of course the worst Beatles albums are still great records, better than most other band’s best records !

I suppose it all depends on what you are after. Some don’t care for their first album… It is almost primitive compared with what was to follow. But it has its place and it has some indispensable songs. Yellow Submarine could be considered their weakest album—it is certainly the hardest one to describe… Not even released as an album in the UK at first… Released in two different forms in the US… It’s title song stolen off of Revolver, the four other songs not strong contenders for greatness (“Hey Bulldog” might be the exception)…. one version of the album having film score music, another a mishmash of A and B side singles…. and yet it is a monument, in some ways, of exactly what was happening with the band at that moment — Confusion and mis-direction. Some say “Let it Be” is weak but it gave us a picture of the Beatles as a performing band again and, despite the misery shown on the film, the record is full of fun and hi-jinks and some really great Beatles classics. At the time of their release, each seemed perfect and inevitable. Looking back with an eye toward history and an understanding of the evolution of pop music, they all fill the right spot at the right time… to judge them with the perspective of a modern ear with no understanding of history is to do them (or any other work of art) a disservice—but even with that kind of an eye, they hold up pretty well. I was in a Walmart recently and “Twist and Shout” was played over the overhead system. Weird. But I’m telling you, that record still rips it up despite all the modern trends and technological advances our ears have been conditioned by. So… I guess it depends on who’s asking and what they actually want to know.

Thanks for A2A! For start, let’s define one thing: my answer takes under consideration only the official Beatles’ discography, according to the UK issues of their albums , plus the US LP-version of “Magical Mystery Tour” - live albums, compilations etc. are not included (besides, there are too many…). So, the questions involves only the official Beatles’ albums, starting chronologically from 1963 with the “Please Please Me” LP and ending in 1970 with the “Let It Be” one (and no, sorry, the “Let It Be - Naked” is NOT a part of their official canon - and that remains a fact). So, according to all that, the answer is pretty obvious, as many others have already pointed out: “Yellow Submarine” (1969) It’s not even a complete Beatles album. The whole second side consists of the musical score for the film and it is not written by the Beatles themselves, but by George Martin (with the notable exception of the last one “Yellow Submarine in Pepperland”. For some reason, I had seperated this track from the others the first - and only- time I heard fully this record side). The first side is a mix of oldies and newer stuff to serve the film (and to finish with contractual obligations), which, I have to say, it’s not that bad at all - on the contrary, I find it pretty amusing and enjoyable! “Hey Bulldog” stands out as the best track of the side, a strong rocker with a kind of sonic attack (plus, a catchy refrain for my ears - i still remember myself playing this song loud at my parents home shouting all over, in a rather cathartic manner, this “You can talk to me / if you ‘re lonely you can talk to me!”). “It’s All Too Much” with its distinctive feedback tone stands very well on its own and, I have to confess, I even enjoyed as a teenager (and, hmmm, sometimes as an adult, as well) the childish “All Together Now” - it may be childish, but it’s also playful and very well-crafted, I admit! OK, “Only A Northern Song” was kind of tedious, which makes it the weakest track. The other two (“Yellow Submarine” and “All You Need Is Love” are older stuff and were presented in previous releases, having gained already a status). This is certainly NOT a bad side of an album - many other bands of the era would struggle to yield an outcome of the same quality, even with its ups and downs. And there comes the side 2 and the whole album becomes flopped. To clarify one thing: GM’s score is not bad, it serves the film pretty well. I cannot remember clearly that music score, in particular, but watching the film (years afterwards) was a pretty fascinating experience and this music score must had its own contribution to this. It simply doesn’t work to be listened seperately, outside the frame of the accompanying film that was written for. This is not something entirely “bad thing”, many film scores / soundtracks don’t stand well on their own - this is the case with that GM’s score. But, being included here on a whole side of a Beatles LP brings an intense feeling of “frustrated expectations” - which is a heavy burden. Plus, it significantly weakens the listening impression of the LP (sorry, mr. Martin!). In conclusion: the mean value of a pretty good side 1 and a, hmmm… flopped, side 2 is a mediocre album. Not bad at all, has its merits, but is by far the weakest spot on the official Beatles canon. If you care of having the “truly best” of the Beatles album, there are plenty of others to choose (picking “Revolver”, for a start). On the other hand, for the completist, owning it is necessary, mandatory I would say - its four “newer” songs at side 1 are not represented anywhere else. PS: As many others have stated, if you are in search for a real bad Beatles’ album, meaning something that is totally crap, sorry, you are looking in the wrong place. There are no real bad albums in the official Beatles’ catalogue. That remains a fact, as well.

Help! It has more original songs than Beatles for Sale (as if that should be some measurement of quality — it isn’t), but the two stellar Lennon singles, “Yesterday” and “I’ve Just Seen a Face" aside, most of the songs are second rate. “You’re Gonna Lose that Girl” is good fun, but “You’ve Got to Hide Your Love Away” is candy-floss Dylan that is saved only by the beautiful vocal in my opinion; the mid-tempo McCartney rockers are dull and the George Harrison songs are awful. “Tell Me What You See” is supremely annoying. All of these songs have interesting bits: the Beatles certainly always tried their hardest to make songs work. “Act Naturally” I kind of like but “Dizzy Miss Lizzy”—compared to the Beatles other Larry Williams covers, especially — is a sloppy mess. I think it would have been improved by taking off the Harrison songs, and the covers and adding the two B-sides, the pleasant enough “Yes It is” and the really rockin’ “I’m Down” which kicks “Dizzy Miss Lizzy”’s sloppily double-tracked ass all over the room. It’s still not a bad album. The heights are very high indeed and the lows are listenable and well-crafted. But I think the strain was telling on them and I think it’s their worst album: yes, worse than Let It Be, which I think is ridiculously underrated, even though I admit that it’s a bit of a mess — which is what makes it such an honest document.

A bad Beatle album doesn’t exist. However, there of course has to be one that’s not as good as the rest, also known as the worst of the best. To me, the album that would take that (dis)honor, not counting live or compilation albums, is Beatles for Sale.  Like I said earlier, there are no bad Beatle albums. Beatles for Sale has some great songs on it. Some highlights from Beatles For Sale are some of my favorite Beatle songs from the pre-Rubber Soul days, like Kansas City and I’m A Loser. However, I would say Beatles For Sale has a considerable amount of covers and throwaway songs that other albums just don’t have. It was released just 21 weeks after A Hard Day’s Night. This is the type of work schedule that The Beatles would end up resenting. Beatles for Sale is an album that shows the band’s fatigue at that point, struggling to produce the high-quality work that they wanted. There are highlights, but overall this album is a low point in a band that was never truly mediocre. We should look back and be thankful for Beatles For Sale, though, as if it weren’t for it, The Beatles would have never tired of the mop-top, touring routine of the early 1960s. If there were no Beatles for Sale, there would have never been a Revolver or a Sgt. Pepper’s. For that, I’m thankful.

Hello. For me it's “Let It Be”. It was recorded under the worst conditions possible. The band didn't like each other much, Lennon was using heroin and chained to Yoko, McCartney was bossing everyone around, George was more interested in Indian music and Ringo just wanted to sit in his garden. They had exhausted all their songwriting with “The White Album” and were out of ideas. McCartney churned out a couple of brilliant ballads and George came up with the catchy “I Me Mine” but Lennon was just devoid of any interest. John did manage to sneak out “Don't Let Me Down” but that's about it. Luckily McCartney realized they can't let those recordings be their last thing together so they upped their game for “Abbey Road”. Their best rock album since “Revolver”.

I would have to say “Let It Be” because I found it to be rather poorly produced. Phil Spector totally wasn’t a good choice to produce the album. I was surprised when I later listened or re-listened to some of his work with The Crystals, The Ronettes, John Lennon, and George Harrison and found the production work to be pretty good. However his production work in my opinion did not belong on a Beatles album. “Let It Be… Naked” is far superior and is actually one of my favourite Beatles albums. I consider “Let It Be… Naked” as the album that “Let It Be” was supposed to be - as did the producers and Paul McCartney that were involved with “Let It Be… Naked”, and various other Beatle fans - and I definitely have no regret in arguing that a true Beatles fan would prefer “Let It Be… Naked” as it was closer to the album’s original intention.

I Think That The Weakest Beatles Album Is The 2 Record Set Titled THE BEATLES Better Known As The White Album.A Good Record Album Needs Continuity And The White Album Had None Of That.Every Song On An Album Should Complement The Others.During The Making Of The DVD The Beatles Anthology,The Remaining Three Were Discussing The White Album.George And Ringo Both Said The White Album Was Spotty And They Should Have Made One Good Album.Paul Was The Only That Disagreed With That.The Beatles Were Starting To Break Up During The White Album And It Showed On The Record.They Were Growing Up Into Men And Developing Their Own Individual Music Styles.The Beatles Were The Only Ones That Broke Up Their Own Group Because Of This.

If we are counting Yellow Submarine, then that is the obvious answer, it’s literally a soundtrack, not an LP, so it may not me counted as an album. If not then the worst Beatles album would probably be Beatles For Sale. Not that it’s bad or anything. I actually really enjoy that album, the thing is that the rest are just much better than it.

Thanks for the A2A. While I am not a big fan of Let It Be, it has quite a few songs that I enjoy, including “I've Got a Feeling”, “I Me Mine”, and “Two of Us”, among others. The one album that I really don't like is Yellow Submarine. For one, about half of the album is the score for the movie. While this is not necessarily bad, I would rather hear the members of The Beatles singing. The only score that I enjoy is “Pepperland”. The rest of the album is not much better either. The only songs that aren't scores that I like from this album are “Hey Bulldog” and “All You Need Is Love”. I feel like “Yellow Submarine” is overrated and I find myself always skipping “Only a Northern Song”, “All Together Now”, and “It’s All Too Much”. That means that, in total, there are only three songs from the entire album that I will listen to. For being a Beatles album, it is a pretty bad album. It is definitely my least favorite Beatles album.

I can only answer which album I listen to the least. But I would still find it hard to say it was bad, let alone the worst. It is Let it be. Probably the only album I have to think twice naming every song on it. May be because it has always reminded me of the end. Maybe because they dropped their standards somewhat. Maybe it is just a taste thing. I really love Help which someone here doesn’t at all.

Assuming that ‘Magical Mystery Tour’ and ‘Yellow Submarine’ don’t count as ‘studio albums’, as the songs on them weren’t recorded with the intention of releasing them as a discrete collection, I’d nominate ‘Beatles for Sale’. It was released only five months after their previous album. ‘A Hard Day’s Night’, and they simply didn’t have enough good material. They had to rush something out for the Christmas market. Obviously, being a Beatles record, it’s still got much to recommend it (especially ‘Eight Days a Week’), but it sounds tired and rushed.

Yellow Submarine. It’s more a Beatles/George Martin Orchestra album than an actual Beatles album due to it being a soundtrack album for the movie of the same name. There’s only a few new songs on the album, the rest of them are either from previous albums or recorded by George Martin’s Orchestra. Some of the songs from the movie don’t even appear on the album and wouldn’t until the 1999 Yellow Submarine Songtrack when the movie was being re-released.

I would nominate Yellow Submarine, which was basically a soundtrack album, half of which was movie score and not even Beatles music. In fact, there were only four original songs not already on other albums. By the way, the album does have one highlight, and a favorite of mine, Hey Bulldog. Not much else to cheer about here. The title track can already be found on Revolver. It’s All Too Much and All Together Now are close to acceptable.

Hi. Consensus seems to be “Yellow Submarine”. But in actuality it's a soundtrack/compilation. Yes, there are four new songs but four songs does not make up an album. My vote goes to: “Magical Mystery Tour". The film, the LP, the EPs…whatever…all of it seems half-baked…(the group were completely baked…but that's another story). And pound for pound…it probably has the weakest running order of any Beatles LP… …until “Let It Be"…my vote for 2nd place. Cheers!

“Let it be”. An unstructured mishmash of poorly produced songs by disillusioned lads, with only few exceptions (like the title song). Luckily, embarrassment and renewed ambition resulted in Abbey Road. (Yellow Submarine, also weak, is not a regular Beatles album)

there are no totally awful Beatle albums…there are always a redeemer tune or three. i love “all too much”.but are there throw away horror tracks? ..sure. “mr. moonlight” for some stupid reason to me is like nails on a blackboard-the cheesy farfisa….etc etc.blah. “you know my name”…oh god.with brian jones no less.. I used to love revolution 9……….then,later on, we had to get up while stoned an skip that track on a vinyl record…thank god for digital remotes,now.

Thank you for your request. Before I proceed know that I am not really a Beatle's fan. I listen to the music occasionally, but I haven't ever owned an album and I do not have any in rotation in my playlists. So, I might not be the best judge. My least favorite album is the “Yellow Submarine” album. Just not my cup of tea and seems out of place with the previous music, but then again maybe I'm just not able to connect it. My kids’ favorite song is on the “White Album" and mine is in “Sergeant Pepper's”.

That is not the way to look at it. The Beatles are like Picasso, Rembrandt, Chaplin or Shakespeare. The entire oeuvre is one piece of art. You can follow their development step by step. Even weak songs are part of the whole, as they learned from their mistakes. All the albums in a row are fascinating musical journey.
In my opinion, Let It Be is their weakest album, though it still has what I consider a few good, solid Beatles songs on it.
Yellow Submarine— but it’s just a soundtrack with only four new tracks, I believe. Of their full albums I’d say Beatles For Sale

Beatles'story It's an american Beatles album that is basically a cashgrab from capitol records It's literally a documentary Made an album with fragments of concerts & songs It's basically a Beatles album without music It's totally pointless ,and useless because after that thousand of better documentaries were Made.
The White Album. Mainly because it should have been cut down to one album and then it would have been really good.
Let It Be
